member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.ArrayBufferBase
member.summary: Array buffer object base class. This class is a specialized for storing data to be issued to a shader program execution.
member.remarks: Implements array buffer, indeed a an array of elements. Implements: - Buffer description: element size and count - Element access (getter and setter) - Creation (CPU, empty, CPU array, GPU empty, GPU array) - Copy-write (CPU array) - Copy-read (CPU array)

member.summary: Determine the OpenGL internal format corresponding to a .

member.returns: It returns a corresponding to the OpenGL enumeration value for the pixel/textel internal format.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.PixelLayoutExtensions.IsSupportedInternalFormat(OpenGL.PixelLayout)
member.summary: Determine whether a is supported by some OpenGL implementation as internal format.
member.param: A to test for OpenGL support.
member.returns: It returns a boolean value indicating whether the current OpenGL implementation supports for the pixel type . The OpenGL support means that texture data could be specified in the pixel format , and it is stored internally with the same pixel format.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.PixelLayoutExtensions.ToDataFormat(OpenGL.PixelLayout)
member.summary: Determine the OpenGL format corresponding to a .
member.param: A to determine the OpenGL format.
member.returns: It returns a corresponding to the OpenGL enumeration value for the pixel/textel format.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.PixelLayoutExtensions.IsSupportedDataFormat(OpenGL.PixelLayout)
member.summary: Determine whether a is supported by current OpenGL implementation as data format.
member.param: A to test for OpenGL support.
member.returns: It returns a boolean value indicating whether the current OpenGL implementation supports for the pixel type . The OpenGL support means that texture data could be specified in the pixel format , but it could be stored in another pixel format.
member.remarks:
The OpenGL support is dependent on what extensions have been implemented by current driver/hardware. The following capabilities are tested: - - - -
The main difference from is that the texture data submission could be specified using a pixel type , but OpenGL driver stores texture data internally using a different pixel format. This could lead to precision loss when specifying data from high-precision pixel formats (such as . Indeed, it is implied that if IsSupportedInternalFormat(type) is true also IsSupportedSetDataFormat(type) is true (but not viceversa).

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.PixelLayoutExtensions.IsSupportedSetDataFormat(OpenGL.PixelLayout,OpenGL.PixelLayout)
member.summary: Determine whether a is supported by current OpenGL implementation as data format for uploading texture data with a specific internal format.
member.param: A to test for OpenGL support as data format in conjunction with the internal format .
A that specify the texture internal format.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.PixelLayoutExtensions.IsSupportedGetDataFormat(OpenGL.PixelLayout,OpenGL.PixelLayout)
member.summary: Determine whether a is supported by current OpenGL implementation as data format for downloading texture data with a specific internal format.
member.param: The underlying texture internal format.

member.summary: Determine the OpenGL data format corresponding to a .
member.param: A to determine the OpenGL data format.
member.returns: It returns a corresponding to .

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.Scene.SceneObjectCodecWavefront.GetPriority(System.String)
member.summary: Determine the plugin priority for a certain sceneObject format.
member.param: An specifying the sceneObject format to test for priority.
member.returns:
It returns an integer value indicating the priority of this implementation respect other ones supporting the same sceneObject format. Conventionally, a value of 0 indicates a totally impartial plugin implementation; a value less than 0 indicates a more confident implementation respect other plugins; a value greater than 0 indicates a fallback implementation respect other plugins.
This implementation of this routine returns -1. The reasoning is that this plugin implementation is very slow in Query and Load, due the .NET abstraction. However, it is a very usefull fallback plugin since it can open the most of common sceneObject formats.

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderProgram.UniformBinding.BlockMatrixRowMajor
member.summary: It's true if the matrix is row-major and the uniform is in a block. false is returned if the uniform is column-major, the uniform is not in a block (all non-block matrices are column-major), or simply not a matrix type.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderProgram.SetVariantUniform(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext,System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Set uniform variable from single-precision floating-point data.
member.param: A used for operations.
A that specify the variable name in the shader source.
A holding the uniform variabile data (first component).

remarks.para: The uniform variable type could be one of the following : - float, vec2, vec3, vec4 - double, dvec2, dvec3, dvec4 - int, ivec2, ivec3, ivec4 - uint, uvec2, uvec3, uvec4
Other components than the first one are reset to 0.0. The single-precision floating-point data is converted accordingly to the uniform variable type.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderProgram.SetVariantUniform(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext,System.String,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Set uniform variable from single-precision floating-point data.
member.param: A used for operations.
A that specify the variable name in the shader source.
A holding the uniform variabile data (first component).
A holding the uniform variabile data (second component).

remarks.para: The uniform variable type could be one of the following : - float, vec2, vec3, vec4 - double, dvec2, dvec3, dvec4 - int, ivec2, ivec3, ivec4 - uint, uvec2, uvec3, uvec4

In the case the uniform variable length is less than 2, the higher components specified as arguments are ignored; otherwise, other components are reset to 0.0. The single-precision floating-point data is converted accordingly to the uniform variable type.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderStorageBuffer.RequiresName(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext)
member.summary: Determine whether this object requires a name bound to a context or not.
member.param: A used for creating this object name.

returns.para: It returns a boolean value indicating whether this GraphicsResource implementation requires a name generation on creation. In the case this routine returns true, the routine will be called (and it must be overriden). In the case this routine returns false, the routine won't be called (and indeed it is not necessary to override it) and a name is generated automatically in a context-independent manner.
This implementation check the GL_ARB_vertex_array_object extension availability.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.CoreImagingImageCodecPlugin.GetPriority(System.String)
member.summary: Determine the plugin priority for a certain image format.
member.param: An specifying the image format to test for priority.
member.returns:
It returns an integer value indicating the priority of this implementation respect other ones supporting the same image format. Conventionally, a value of 0 indicates a totally impartial plugin implementation; a value less than 0 indicates a more confident implementation respect other plugins; a value greater than 0 indicates a fallback implementation respect other plugins.
This implementation of this routine returns -1. The reasoning is that this plugin implementation is very slow in Query and Load, due the .NET abstraction. However, it is a very usefull fallback plugin since it can open the most of common image formats.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext
member.summary: Graphics context.

remarks.para: A GraphicsContext represents an attachment to the graphic operations. It actually store the graphic state, which determines the graphical pipeline results.

To construct a GraphicsContext instance, it is necessary a device context. The device context is a OS handle which represents a specific graphical device. You can note that there are constructors which does not require a device context parameter: in this cases a common device context is used implicitly.

Respect a particoular version requested, it is possible that the current OpenGL implementation returns a context that doesn't have the exact OpenGL version requested. In this cases it is assured that the OpenGL version requested it is implemented (i.e. actual OpenGL version is a superset of the requested one).
Without those OpenGL extensions, it won't be possible to request a different OpenGL implementation from the current one, which is queriable by accessing to .

It is possible to share resources with other GraphicsContext instances by specifying a GraphicsContext parameter at construction time. The resources could be shared are listed in . There can be sharing compatibility issues by sharing resources having different OpenGL implementations.
As generale rule, when an OpenGL version introduce a new object space class not implemented by another version, those two OpenGL version cannot share object spaces.

GraphicsContext define OpenGL implementation capabilities with the type . This type collection useful information about a specific OpenGL implementation. It defines general information, implementation limits and extension support.
GraphicsContext exposes the current implementation capabilities by the static property . This information is static, and it represent the most extended implementation currently available. Normally this property is not used for testing OpenGL support and limits, since this information is dependent on the current context, which could not be a GraphicsContext with the current OpenGL version (because it is possible to request a specific OpenGL implementation version).
Since each OpenGL implementation version can support any OpenGL extension combination, each GraphicsContext has its own OpenGL support, which could differ from the current OpenGL support.
Because this, all methods which depends on OpenGL support take a parameter of type GraphicsContext: that parameter is used to test effective support and limits for the specific OpenGL context. Testing OpenGL context capabilities by means of could lead to invalid operations since those capabilities are not referred to the currently bound context.
Since the device context is constructed by specifying a device context, it is able to detect ... remove public interface!

Before any operation, the GraphicsContext has to be current. Only one current context per thread is allowed, but multiple context can made current on a thread one at time. Once a GraphicsContext is current on a thread, it is possible to issue rendering commands, and the rendering commands result is dependent on the current GraphicsContext.
Issuing rendering commands without having a current context on the thread will lead to exceptions.
A GraphicsContext is made current by calling . It is possible to check the GraphicsContext currency by calling , or getting the current GraphicsContext for the thread by calling .

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsResource
member.summary: Any resource that is involved in the graphics operations.

remarks.para: This class in the main implementation of the interface. This is the suggested implementation; in the case it is not possible to inherit class (i.e. a class is already inheriting from another one), it is possible to implement directly the .

Most of the IGraphicsResource interface is implemented. The GraphicsResource inheritors shall implement the following methods: - : this method is virtual and it always throw a . It shall generate an object name of a specific object class (determined by inheritor). It is called in the implementation. - : this method is virtual, and it can be overriden to actually create an useful object. Base implementation is empty. It is called in the implementation, after . - : this method is abstract, and it shall delete the object name and resources of this GraphicsResource instance. The implementation is dependent on the specific object class (determined by inheritor). - : this method is virtual, but throw always . Inheritor shall override this method since the implementation is dependent on the specific object class (determined by inheritor).

This class defines also an invalid object name . Despite the name, this field doesn't actually specify an invalid object name for all object classes. OpenGL specification usually uses this value for indicating an invalid object name, but it is not always the case (i.e. for framebuffer objects, InvalidObjectName indicates the default framebuffer object).
However, this name shall never be generated from .

member.summary: Determine whether this object requires a name bound to a context or not.

returns.para: It returns a boolean value indicating whether this GraphicsResource implementation requires a name generation on creation. In the case this routine returns true, the routine will be called (and it must be overriden). In the case this routine returns false, the routine won't be called (and indeed it is not necessary to override it) and a name is generated automatically in a context-independent manner.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsResource.Exists(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext)
member.summary: Determine whether this GraphicsResource really exists.
member.param: A that would have created (or a sharing one) the object. This context shall be current.
member.returns: It returns a boolean value indicating whether this object exists in the object space of .

remarks.para: The current implementation actually does not test for object existence, but it tests for object name space correspondence, indicating a relationship between this GraphicsResource and the GraphicsContext used for creating this resource.

Inheritors that managed an OpenGL resource shall override this method in order to check the effective existence of this GraphicsResource agains . In counterpart, if the resource is not managed directly by OpenGL, this routine could be leaved as is.

member.exception: Exception thrown if is null.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsResource.Create(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext)
member.summary: Create this GraphicsResource.
member.param: A used for creating this object. The object space of this is used to generate , and all contextes sharing lists with this parameter can handle this IGraphicsResource. The shall be current to the calling thread.

remarks.para: After this method, the resource must be in a "working" state, having all context-dependent information defined in the object namespace of the context .

This method shall be the preferred way to allocate graphic resources. The allocation happens in the object namespace of , and an object cannot be allocated for more than one context at time. The normal way is to share the object namespace between different instances of (de-facto they share the same object namespace.
After a successfull call to Create, shall return true.

The actual implementation does: - Creates an object name, if required. It the current implementation requires an object name () it calls method; otherwise, it automatically generate resource name based on property (resources having the same class will never have name conflicts, even of different render contextes). - Create the object. The actual implementation of the object creation is defined by method.
In some GraphicsResource implementation is allowed to have null context resources (i.e. ).

member.exception: Exception thrown if is null.
Exception thrown if is not current to the calling thread.
Exception thrown if the object has been already created.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsResource.Delete(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext)
member.summary: Delete this GraphicsResource.
member.param: A used for deleting this object. The IGraphicsResource shall belong to the object space to this . The shall be current to the calling thread.

remarks.para: After this method, the resource must have deallocated every graphic resource associated with it. Normally it should be possible to create again the resources by calling .
This methods shall be the preferred way to deallocate graphic resources.
After a successfull call to Create, shall return true.

The actual implementation deletes the name () only if the implementation requires a context related name (). In the case derived classes requires more complex resource deletion pattern, this method could be overriden for that purpose, paying attention to call the base implementation.

member.exception: Exception thrown if is null.
Exception thrown if this object doesn't exists for (this is determined by calling method), or this resource has a name and is not current to the calling thread.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsResource.Dispose(OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsContext)
member.summary: Dispose graphics resources using the underlying .
member.param: A which have access to the graphics resources.

remarks.para: The instance shall be considered disposed as it were called , but in addition this method will release this instance resources.
The method should try to release the underlying resources by getting the optional graphics context current on the calling thread.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.GraphicsSurface
member.summary: Graphics surface interface.

remarks.para: A GraphicsSurface is able to store the result of a rendering operation. This class represents the final component of a RenderPipeline, but it could be used as data source for another RenderPipeline.
A GraphicsSurface is defined by a set of buffers; each buffer is defined by a type, which specify the how use the buffer contents. Each buffer type defines the available formats for data storage.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.IGraphicsResource
member.summary: Interface used for allocating and releasing graphics objects.

remarks.para: This interface defines a common interface for those objects which are allocated on an OpenGL context. These objects belongs to one of the following classes: - Display list (actually not supported) - Textures object () - Buffer object () - Shader object () - Shader program () - Shader program pipeline (actually not supported) - Render buffer object () - Framebuffer object () - Query object (actually not supported) - Sync object (actually not supported) - Transform feedback object (actually not supported)

These object classes can be shared between different instances, constructed in the proper way. Actually current OpenGL specification are not officially supporting all those object classes, but in the real world it actually works thanks to drivers implementations.

The IGraphicsResource exposes methods and properties which enable the interface user to identify the object by a name (). It also enable the interface user to check effectively the IGraphicsResource existence ().

The IGraphicsResource defines methods used for allocating and releasing object resources (, . The methods and are context dependent, since the object creation and deletion is dependent on the current context of the executing thread.

The object deletion (using requires a current context on the calling thread. This cannot be always true, because design limitation (i.e. IGraphicsResource inherit IDisposable) or because application design (i.e. multithreading); but if the IGraphicsResource is not deleted by , it causes a resource leak on an OpenGL context.
To avoid the resource leaks, it was introduced the , which is a garbage collector of IGraphicsResource instances. Pratically, a IGraphicsResource can be deleted in successive stages by collecting it in the only instance, and later request to delete all objects belonging to a .
Here it comes the method. This method have the same functionality of , but without requiring a current context. Ideally, a tipical implementation of this method would garbage the IGraphicsResource instance (by interacting with ). However, it is necessary to schedule the object delection by using .

The IGraphicsResource interface inherits from . The IDisposable implementation is used to ensure object resources by means of the using construct. Tipically implementation shall call , since it cannot be sure what (and if a) is current on the calling thread.

A direct implementation of this interface is the class, which it can be inherited. This class implements most of IGraphicsResource interface, leaving to the inheritor a few ones to overrides. This is the suggested way to implement the IGraphicsResource interface, but there can be some special cases which is necessary the interface inherition; in the case implements the interface following the interface guidelines.

remarks.para: The object class identify the resource type. It cannot be , but a meaninfull value. The allowed values are determined in the concrete implementation of the IGraphicsResource implementation.

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ImageCodecCriteria.QualityPreset
member.summary: Floating-point value used by selected plugins to determine some generic quality preset.

remarks.para: The plugin can ignore the quality setting specified. The value is normalized in the range [0.0, 1.0], where 1.0 means the highest quality. Usually this preset shall not reduce fundamental image parameters, such as image extents or pixel precision.

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ImageCodecCriteria.SoftwareSupport
member.summary: Boolean value used by selected plugin to determine whether to convert image in order to support hardware formats.

remarks.para: The plugin will check whether the native pixel format is available on current hardware. In the case hardware is not capable to represent the image and this criteria is set to false, then the plugin refuse to load the image. Otherwise, it try to convert the image pixel format in order to have a pixel format compatible with the hardware.

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ImageFormat.Raw
member.summary: RAW camera container.
member.remarks:
".3fr": Hasselblad Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".arw": Sony Digital Camera Raw Image Format for Alpha devices. ".bay": Casio Digital Camera Raw File Format. ".bmq": NuCore Raw Image File. ".cap": Phase One Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".cine": Phantom Software Raw Image File. ".cr2": Canon Digital Camera RAW Image Format version 2.0. These images are based on the TIFF image standard. ".crw": Canon Digital Camera RAW Image Format version 1.0. extList.Add(".cs1": Sinar Capture Shop Raw Image File. ".dc2": Kodak DC25 Digital Camera File. ".dcr": Kodak Digital Camera Raw Image Format for these models: Kodak DSC Pro SLR/c, Kodak DSC Pro SLR/n, Kodak DSC Pro 14N, Kodak DSC PRO 14nx. ".drf": Kodak Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".dsc": Kodak Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".dng": Adobe Digital Negative: DNG is publicly available archival format for the raw files generated by digital cameras. By addressing the lack of an open standard for the raw files created by individual camera models, DNG helps ensure that photographers will be able to access their files in the future. ".erf": Epson Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".fff": Imacon Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".ia": Sinar Raw Image File. ".iiq": Phase One Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".k25": Kodak DC25 Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".kc2": Kodak DCS200 Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".kdc": Kodak Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".mdc": Minolta RD175 Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".mef": Mamiya Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".mos": Leaf Raw Image File. ".mrw": Minolta Dimage Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".nef": Nikon Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".nrw": Nikon Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".orf": Olympus Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".pef": Pentax Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".ptx": Pentax Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".pxn": Logitech Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".qtk": Apple Quicktake 100/150 Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".raf": Fuji Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".raw": Panasonic Digital Camera Image Format. ".rdc": Digital Foto Maker Raw Image File. ".rw2": Panasonic LX3 Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".rwl": Leica Camera Raw Image Format. ".rwz": Rawzor Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".sr2": Sony Digital Camera Raw Image Format. ".srf": Sony Digital Camera Raw Image Format for DSC-F828 8 megapixel digital camera or Sony DSC-R1 ".sti": Sinar Capture Shop Raw Image File.
FileExtensions = "3fr|arw|bay|bmq|cap|cine|cr2|crw|cs1|dc2|dcr|drf|dsc|dng|erf|fff|ia|iiq|k25|kc2|kdc|mdc|mef|mos|mrw|nef|nrw|orf|pef|ptx|pxn|qtk|raf|raw|rdc|rw2|rwl|rwz|sr2|srf|sti"

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.IResource.IncRef
member.summary: Increment the shared IResource reference count.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.IResource.DecRef
member.summary: Decrement the shared IResource reference count.

remarks.para: Decrementing the reference count for this resource could cause this instance disposition. In the case the reference count equals 0 (with or without decrementing it), this instance will be disposed using .

This method should be meant almost equals to method (since it can dispose conditionally the instance). Sadly, code analysis tools could detect that IDisposable fields won't be disposed by some classes.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.RenderBuffer
member.summary: Framebuffer attachable render buffer.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.RenderBuffer.#ctor(OpenGL.Objects.RenderBuffer.Type,OpenGL.PixelLayout,System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Construct a render buffer.
member.param: A that specify the type of the buffer. This parameter influence the framebuffer attachment, and the possible formats.

A that specify the internal OpenGL format for this RenderBuffer. From OpenGL 3.2 specification: @verbatim Implementations are required to support the same internal formats for renderbuffers as the required formats for textures enumerated in section 3.8.1, with the exception of the color formats labelled texture-only. Requesting one of these internal formats for a renderbuffer will allocate at least the internal component sizes and exactly the component types shown for that format in tables 3.12- 3.13. @endverbatim

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderCompilerContext

remarks.para: This class shall group all elements which influence the compilation process: - Shading Language version - Preprocessor symbols (i.e. #define statements) - Preprocessor include paths - Extension directives (i.e. #extension statements) - Feedback buffer format

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderExtensionBehavior.Warn
member.summary: Behave as specified by the extension extension_name, except issue warnings on any detectable use of that extension, unless such use is supported by other enabled or required extensions.
member.remarks: If all is specified, then warn on all detectable uses of any extension used.

member.name: F:OpenGL.Objects.ShaderExtensionBehavior.Disable
member.summary: Behave (including issuing errors and warnings) as if the extension extension_name is not part of the language definition.

remarks.para: If all is specified, then behavior must revert back to that of the non-extended core version of the language being compiled to.
Warn on the #extension if the extension extension_name is not supported.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.Shader
member.summary: Shader object.

remarks.para: A Shader is a function library allowing to compose a ShaderProgram. The Shader is characterized by its source code; the source code has to be compiled, before being linked with a ShaderProgram instance. A single Shader could be linked with one or more ShaderProgram instances. Once linked, it doesn't have the reason to be allocated anymore (except for reuse in another program linkage).

A Shader instance has a main class, which determine the execution stage of the code, when the formed ShaderProgram is executed. The avaialable classes depends on the current OpenGL implementation; at the current state, the shader object class is determined by the enumeration .

This class automatically builds the source code of each Shader. The generated source code has the following strings: - Standard shader header - Linked shader program preprocessor definitions (conditional symbols) - This shader source strings
The standard header is composed from standard pragmas (current shader version, debug or optimization pragmas). This source in invariant.
Shader program preprocessor definitions are supplied by the ShaderProgram holding the Shader. Indeed preprocessor definitions are shared between every Shader linked with the same ShaderProgram.

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.State.GraphicsStateSet
member.summary: A set of GraphicsState.

remarks.para: This class collects instances to specify a set of parameters that affect drawing operations. Each instance is applied, replacing the previous state having the same type ().

Usually rendering operations are ordered by the state they requires, and the order is meant to minimize the state changes. The state is applied only if the actually one is different to the one to be applied. This operation is performed using Merge method.

member.name: M:OpenGL.Objects.State.GraphicsStateSet.Merge(OpenGL.Objects.State.GraphicsStateSet)
member.summary: Merge this state set with another one.
member.param: A to be merged with this GraphicsStateSet.

remarks.para: After a call to this routine, this GraphicsStateSet store the union of the previous information and of the information of .
The semantic of the merge result is dependent by each defined in both state sets.

In the case a kind of GraphicsState is defined only in this GraphicsStateSet, the specific state remains unchanged, except when the state is not inheritable; in this case the specific state will be undefined.
In the case a kind of GraphicsState is defined only in , that state will be defined equally in this GraphicsStateSet.
In the case a kind of GraphicsState is defined by both state sets, the state defined in this GraphicsStateSet will be merged with the one defined in , by calling .

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.Texture
member.summary: Texture.

remarks.para: Textures are object holding a set of data, that can be accessed within a shader using a set of coordinates. Textures classes derives from , which define a base implementation without specifying the texture dimensionality.
Texture can be one dimensional (), two dimensional (), three dimensional (), cube mapped ().

member.name: T:OpenGL.Objects.VertexArrays
member.summary: A collection of vertex arrays and vertex indices.

remarks.para: Vertex arrays are collected by semantic or name. The array buffers corresponding to vertex attributes can have any memory layout (offset and interleaving).
Vertex arrays are rendered using a collection of vertex elements. Each vertex element issue a rendering command, referencing the vertex array data directly or using a deferencing index.
A vertex array can have associated a shader program, and an render state set. Those two objects defines the rendering result of the collected arrays.
